subject: RE: [junit] Regarding Repeated Test
msgSnippet: ... The first time round, it has to load in class definitions, compile the bytecode to machine code, etc. This would result in a large performance hit that
messageBody:
RE: [junit] Regarding Repeated Test

Bala Subramanian writes:
> Hi Junit Experts
>         I have a query .I hope u can help me .
>         I am using repeated test in junit for a particular function .
>         The test is successfully run and it gives a time
> taken for each
> iteration .
>         There is a large time difference between first time excuting
>         function and second ,third so on .Why time is getting
>         reduced .I didn't understand the concept .Could
>         anyone of you  give me some information regarding that

The first time round, it has to load in class definitions, compile the bytecode to machine code, etc. This would result in a large performance hit that first time.

After that, the optimising virtual machine (HotSpot) would be doing its stuff. Essentially, Java code gets faster, the more times it is run within a given JVM (to a point of diminishing returns).

If you're trying to do the repeats to gain a feel for how fast the code performs, I suggest running a large number of tests (> 100). The effects will diminish over time.

In addition, you may notice some large jumps in the time taken. This is because the JVM has either been kicked off the CPU by the operating system, or garbage collection has occurred.

Robert.
